Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature \( T \) across a rod varies over time and can be described by the heat equation \( \\frac{\\partial T}{\\partial t} = k \\frac{\\partial^2 T}{\\partial x^2} \) where \( k \) is the thermal diffusivity constant. An external heat source modifies the initial temperature distribution as \( f(T) = T_0 + h \\sin(\\omega x) \) where \( T_0 \) is the initial uniform temperature, \( h \) is the amplitude, and \( \\omega \) the frequency of the heat variation.

If at time \( t_1 \), an intervention happens where the temperature distribution is altered by an additional function \( g(T) = T + q \\cos(\\phi x) \) (where \( q \) and \( \\phi \) are constants), will the temperature at a later time \( t = T \) only rely on the post-intervention state and not on the initial function \( f(T) \)?
Explanation: The final temperature distribution \( T(x, T) \) will be influenced by both the initial function \( f(T) \) and the intervention \( g(T) \). The effects of \( f(T) \) might still be present albeit diminished, and will interplay with the impacts of \( g(T) \).
